entry.title: Bayesian Inference
entry.content:
source source

This post is a personal review post on the Bayesian Inference.

Prior and Posterial Probabilities

pictorial illustration

A tree diagram would be the simplest way to illustrate the approach.

The left and right sides show prior and posterial probabilities, respectively. Given the prior probabilities P(A)P(A)P(A) and P(B)P(B)P(B) (which is 1−P(A)1-P(A)1−P(A) by definition), the posterial probabilities P(A∣C)P(A|C)P(A∣C), P(B∣C)P(B|C)P(B∣C), P(A∣D)P(A|D)P(A∣D) and P(B∣D)P(B|D)P(B∣D) are the updated probabilities after taking into account the events CCC and DDD (which is the complement of CCC).

formal derivation

The formal derivation is simple

Examples

Covid (or any medical) test

Notation:

  • YYY and NNN are the events of being infected or not infected from Covid, respectively.
  • +++ and −-− indicates the test results, positive and negative, respectively.

Prior probabilities: The test kit should disclose

  • sensitivity (true positive rate): P(+∣Y)P(+|Y)P(+∣Y)
  • specificity (true negative rate): P(−∣N)P(-|N)P(−∣N)

Table with all prior probabilities:

test \ covid Y N
+ P(+∥Y)P(+|Y)P(+∥Y): sensitivity, true positive P(+∥N)P(+|N)P(+∥N): false positive
- P(−∥Y)P(-|Y)P(−∥Y): false negative P(−∥N)P(-|N)P(−∥N): specificity, true negative
sum 1 1

Posterior probabilities: When we perform a test, we would like to know

  • P(Y∣+)P(Y|+)P(Y∣+): correct test result
  • P(Y∣−)P(Y|-)P(Y∣−): incorrect test result

Table with all posterial probabilities:

test \ covid Y N sum
+ P(Y∥+)P(Y|+)P(Y∥+): correct P(N∥+)P(N|+)P(N∥+): incorrect 1
- P(Y∥−)P(Y|-)P(Y∥−): incorrect P(N∥−)P(N|-)P(N∥−): correct 1

Now, let’s consider the RLF test kit, which has 99.9% sensitivity, or
P(+∣Y)=P(−∣N)=0.999P(+|Y) = P(-|N) = 0.999P(+∣Y)=P(−∣N)=0.999
Then, we have
P(Y∣+)=P(+∣Y)P(Y)P(+∣Y)P(Y)+P(+∣N)P(N)P(Y|+) = \frac{P(+|Y)P(Y)}{P(+|Y)P(Y) + P(+|N)P(N)}P(Y∣+)=P(+∣Y)P(Y)+P(+∣N)P(N)P(+∣Y)P(Y)​
and
P(Y∣−)=P(−∣Y)P(Y)P(−∣Y)P(Y)+P(−∣N)P(N)P(Y|-) = \frac{P(-|Y)P(Y)}{P(-|Y)P(Y) + P(-|N)P(N)}P(Y∣−)=P(−∣Y)P(Y)+P(−∣N)P(N)P(−∣Y)P(Y)​

The prior infection probability P(Y)=1−P(N)P(Y) = 1-P(N)P(Y)=1−P(N) is varied between 0 and 0.001 (0.1%), and an alternative sensitivity assumption 0.990.990.99 (rubbish kit) is also considered:

Suppose that the prevailing infection probabilty is at 1/1000. If the test kit shows a positive result, I have about 50% chance to have a Covid. In comparison, a positive result from a rubbish kit means about 10% chance. In both cases, if negative test result means that there is almost no chance to have a Covid (so, you can go out).

entry.title: Debug Jupyter Python Notebook via VS Code
entry.content:
VS Code finally supports debugging for Jupyter Notebook. See ‘October 2021 Release’. So the following is obsolete!

Background

When writing a notebook using Jupyter (Notebook or Lab), it is common to write actual codes as separate modules (.py) and call them from the notebook. In this post, we show how to use VS Code debugger from Jupyter to debug (i) cells within Jupyter and (ii) codes in .py files. Surprisingly, I couldn’t find any memos explaining this elsewhere.

Preparation

  • Install debugpy
  • Add a new config in VS Code

    • click the bug/triangle button on the left.

    • click the gear button. This will open launch.json

    • click Add Configuration -> Python -> Remote Attach

    • simply accept the defaults (host = localhost, port = 5678) by pressing enters twice.

    • This will create an additional config

Action

  • Here is an example:
VS Code Jupyter
  • From Jupyter: Execute step 3.
  • Go back to VS Code and Select Python: Remote Attach and click the green triange
  • Then, you will be connected and should be able to see the following:
  • From Jupyter, exceute step 4. The breakpoint() command invokes a debug activity.
  • Then, go back to VS Code. The cell is copied into a temperary file in VS Code. You can debug the codes in the usual way.

entry.title: Using FFTW and pyFFTW
entry.content:
Xk=∑k=0N−1e−2πik/NxiX_{k} = \sum_{k=0}^{N-1} e^{-2\pi i k / N} x_iXk​=k=0∑N−1​e−2πik/Nxi​

FFTW is a popular C-library for computing the discrete Fourier transform and its documentation page provides comprehesive information on the library. For Python, pyFFTW provides an excellent wrapper. Below, we show a simple example in both C and Python versions to illustrate how the Python wrapper corresponds to the actual library.

Example

The example does the follow calls:

  • allocate spaces for x, y, and z (z_N in C version), each of which has N complex numbers.
  • set up fft and ifft plans.
    • fft: from x to y
    • ifft: from y to z (z_N in C version)
  • fill x with cos(3 * pi * t) and call fft to get y.
  • fill x with cos(5 * pi * t) and call fft to get a different y.
  • call ifft on y to get z (z_N in C version)
  • compared to x.
    • In C, z_N is the same to x * N because the library does not include the scale factor.
    • In Python, z is the same to x because the wrapper adds the scale factor.

Both versions together

To see both versions together, click the image below. The left panel is in C and the right panel is in Python. Extra spaces are added to the Python version so that the two versions are aligned line-by-line.

Codes: C

Codes: Python

entry.title: Illustration of Volatility Clustering using Garch
Linear Projection
entry.content:
The purpose of this page is to review (mostly to remind myself of) topics related to conditional expectations and linear projections of random variables. The content of this page is based on Chapter 4, Time Series Analysis by Hamiton, which provides more general and detailed expositions.

Triangular Factorisation

Description

For any positive-definite symmetric matrix Ω\OmegaΩ, we can apply the triangular factorisation:

where

  • AAA is a lower triangular matrix with 1s along the diagonal.
  • DDD is a diagonal matrix with postive diagonal entries.

Note that ′'′ is used to represent the transpose operator.

Illustrations

The triangular factorisation is nothing but a series of Guassian eliminations in both rows and columns.

2x2 matrix

As the simplest illustration, suppose that Ω\OmegaΩ in a 2×22 \times 22×2 matrix:

To factorise this matrix,

  • Eliminate Ω21\Omega_{21}Ω21​ by multiplying the first row by −Ω21/Ω11-\Omega_{21}/\Omega{11}−Ω21​/Ω11 and adding to the second row.
  • Similarly, eliminate Ω12\Omega{12}Ω12 by multiplying the the first column by −Ω12/Ω11-\Omega_{12}/\Omega{11}−Ω12​/Ω11 and adding to the second column.

Then, we obtain

Invert the matrices surrounding Ω\OmegaΩ to obtain


Since Ω\OmegaΩ is symmetric, this can be written as ADA′A D A'ADA′ where

2x2 block matrix**

The above calculation with a 2x2 matrix extends to a 2x2 block matrix as well. To this end, suppose that Ω11\Omega_{11}Ω11​ and Ω22\Omega_{22}Ω22​ are n×nn \times nn×n and m×mm \times mm×m matrices, respectively. Then, we have


Since Ω\OmegaΩ is symmetric, this can be written as ADA′A D A'ADA′ where

3x3 matrix

Consider a 3x3 matrix:

As before, perform a series of Gauassian row and column elimations (expressed using E1E_1E1​ and E1′E_1'E1′​ below) with Ω11\Omega_{11}Ω11​ as the pivot to get

where

and

  • H22=Ω22−Ω21Ω11−1Ω12H_{22} = \Omega_{22} - \Omega_{21}\Omega_{11}^{-1}\Omega_{12}H22​=Ω22​−Ω21​Ω11−1​Ω12​
  • H23=H32=Ω23−Ω21Ω11−1Ω13H_{23} = H_{32} = \Omega_{23} - \Omega_{21} \Omega_{11}^{-1}\Omega_{13}H23​=H32​=Ω23​−Ω21​Ω11−1​Ω13​
  • H33=Ω33=Ω31Ω11−1Ω13H_{33} = \Omega{33} = \Omega_{31}\Omega_{11}^{-1}\Omega_{13}H33​=Ω33=Ω31​Ω11−1​Ω13​

Now, perform the Gauassian elimations using H22H_{22}H22​ as the pivot to get

where

Set A=(E2E1)−1A = (E_2 E_1)^{-1}A=(E2​E1​)−1 to get

3x3 block matrix

Again, the above calculations for a 3x3 matrix extends to a 3x3 block matrix.

MORE TO COME

entry.title: Navier Stokes 2D Simulation
entry.content:
Kelvin Helmholtz 2D Turbulence

This post is about simulating the 2D incompressible Navier Stokes equations in a rectangular domain with the period boundary conditions in both axes. This was a topic I studied in my graduate school days when I used C/C++ and Fortran to implement the core model and Matlab for plotting purposes. The purpose of this post is just for me to remind of those equations and techniques back for no particular reason.

Equations

The 3D incompressible Navier-Stokes equations (wiki) are given by

where u⃗=[u,v,w]\vec{u} = [u,v,w]u=[u,v,w] is the velocity vector field, ppp is the pressure field, and DDt\frac{D}{Dt}DtD​ is the material derivative, defined as
DDt=∂∂t+u⃗⋅∇⃗.\frac{D}{Dt} = \frac{\partial}{\partial t} + \vec{u}\cdot \vec{\nabla}.DtD​=∂t∂​+u⋅∇.

If restricted to the 2D case where w=0w = 0w=0, we can introduce a stream function ψ\psiψ such that

so that the divergence-free condition ∇⋅u⃗=0\nabla\cdot \vec{u} = 0∇⋅u=0 is satisfied. Taking the curl ∇⃗×\vec{\nabla} \times∇× of the first NS equation, the third component becomes

In terms of vorticity ω=−∇2ψ\omega = - \nabla^2 \psiω=−∇2ψ,

Numerical Simulation using Spectral Method

If the periodic boundary condition is assumed, it is straightforward to implement the 2D equation using the standard spectral method with a standard ODE solver such as Runge-Kutta methods.

Fourier Transform

To this end, take the (discrete) Fourier transform F\mathcal FF of ()

where ω^(k⃗)\hat{\omega}(\vec{k})ω^(k) is the Fourier coefficient at the Fourier model k⃗\vec{k}k and JJJ is the nonlinear term (known as Jacobian)
J=∂ψ∂y∂ω∂x−∂ψ∂x∂ω∂y.J = \frac{\partial \psi}{\partial y} \frac{\partial \omega}{\partial x} - \frac{\partial \psi}{\partial x} \frac{\partial \omega}{\partial y}.J=∂y∂ψ​∂x∂ω​−∂x∂ψ​∂y∂ω​.
and F[J]\mathcal F \left[J\right]F[J] is its Fourier transform.

Time integration

While one may apply an ODE solver directly to (), we can first integrate the diffusion term analytically for each time step.

We apply the standrad RK4 method (wiki) to the above system of equations over k⃗\vec{k}k‘s. For stabilty of the scheme, the time step δt\delta tδt is set to be small enough so that an appropriate CFL condition is met (see wiki). In particular, we consider the following CFL value based on the Jacobian term in ()

and ensure it to be within the RK4 stability region, or
C<Cmax⁡≈2.8.C < C_{\max} \approx 2.8.C<Cmax​≈2.8.
Note that the diffusion term is not considered in specifying CCC as it is analytically integrated in ().

Discrete Fourier Transform

A python wrapper pyfftw to a very popular FFT liborary FFTW is used to compute any discrete Fourier transformations. See also my own post fftw. For a 1D array, for example, the wrapper provides (i) the forward “physical to Fourier” tranfrom

and (ii) the backward “Fourier to phyiscal” transform

Fourier decomposition

For a function u(x)u(x)u(x) periodic in [0,L][0, L][0,L], its Fourier decomposition is written as

where the kkk-th wave-length is 2πk/L2\pi k /L2πk/L.

Calculation of Jacobian and Dealiasing

To calculate the Fourier transform of the products appearing in the Jacobian term, we use the standard procedure:

  1. apply the `3/2’ rule to pad zeros around the Fourier coefficients of each variables; this is to avoid the aliasing effect (wiki) arising from a product of two variables.
  2. apply the inverse transform to each variable to go back to the phyiscal domain.
  3. point-wise multiplication.
  4. apply the forward transform.
  5. extract the 2/3 (in each axis) of the result to align to the original resolution.

An (bad) alternative would be to apply an convolution, which is a slow N2N^2N2 operation, while the above procedure is about Nln⁡(N)N \ln(N)Nln(N).

Diagnostics

Energy

The kinetic energy EEE is given by

where LxL_xLx​ and LyL_yLy​ are the domain lengths for xxx and yyy, respectively.
It can be expressed in terms of Fourier modes as

where MxM_xMx​ and MyM_yMy​ are the number of sampling points in xxx and yyy, respectively.
In terms of ψ^\hat \psiψ^​, we have

entry.title: Numba is fast and can be faster than Numpy
entry.content:
Source Codes:

  • Jupyter notebook
  • folder

Background

Personally, numpy is the most important package because of its vectorisation implementation. Generally speaking, it makes the code shorter, easier to read, and most importantly faster, in fact, much faster if compared to nativa Python. But, the catch is generally. Certain algorithms or procedures are not natually vectorisable and the resulting vectorised codes can have awkward structures that are difficult to read. They may also introduce uncessary but unavoidable overheads. This problem can be solved using numba, which compiles python codes behind-the-scene into fast machine codes.

Illustration: Using Markov Chain Monte Carlo Simulation

Recently, I had to implement to simulate a Markov chain model, requiring a large number of Monte Carlo scenarios (order of 10M). We started using numpy and it was fast. But, we wanted faster, and realised that the model is a good example where the vectorisation approach adds unnessary overheads that are unavoidable with numpy. So, we considered numba.

Markov Chain


Source: Wikipedia

A (discrete-time) markov chain is a stochastic model with many real life applications. See the relevant Wikipedia page for more information. The model is described in terms of

  • a finite set of states
  • transition probabilities from one state to another state

To simulate a markov chain,

  • set the intial state
  • draw a uniform random number between 0 and 1
  • compare to the cumulative transition probabilities to determine the next state
  • repeat

Implementation

For benchmark purposes, three functions are implemented to simulate the model:

  1. Native Python
  2. Native Python with numby (via njit)
  3. Numpy implementation

Here is a code block. Only the first function is documented. The other two functions have the same arguments and return values.

Observe that the native Python code, which is numba’ed, is as simple as the numpy version. In fact, I argue that it is simpler and easier to understand.

Simulations

First, the number of states should be specified together with the transition probabilities among them. The cumulative probabilities are required as inputs to the simulation

Then, we simulate the model over several steps for a large number of scenarios.

Results

  • When 1M scenarios over 10 steps are used: The numba verison (0.12 seconds) is

    • over 50 time faster than the naive version (6.7 seconds)
    • over 3 time faster than the numpy version (0.43 seconds)

  • When 10M scenarios are used, the numba version (1.39 seconds) is again over 3 times fater than the numpy version (4.98 seconds).

In Closing

In this post, we have provided an illustrative example where numba can be used to speed up Markov chain simulations. Not only the numba’ed native Python code is actually simpler than the numpy version, it is noticeably faster; in our experiments, over 3 times faster.

So, numba is a great supplementary package that can be utilised when procedures/algorithms are not easily vectorisable.
